case_vignette: A 34-year-old Ethiopian woman who recently moved to the United States presents for evaluation to a surgical outpatient clinic with painful ulceration in her right breast for the last 2 months. She is worried because the ulcer is increasing in size. On further questioning, she says that she also has a discharge from her right nipple. She had her 2nd child 4 months ago and was breastfeeding the baby until the pain started getting worse in the past few weeks, and is now unbearable. According to her health records from Africa, her physician prescribed antimicrobials multiple times with a diagnosis of mastitis, but she did not improve significantly. Her mother and aunt died of breast cancer at 60 and 58 years of age, respectively. On examination, the right breast is enlarged and firm, with thickened skin, diffuse erythema, edema, and an ulcer measuring 3 × 3 cm. White-Gray nipple discharge is present. The breast is tender with axillary and cervical adenopathy. Mammography is ordered, which shows a mass with a large area of calcifications, parenchymal distortion, and extensive soft tissue and trabecular thickening in the affected breast. The patient subsequently undergoes core-needle and full-thickness skin punch biopsies. The pathology report states a clear dermal lymphatic invasion by tumor cells.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a painful ulcer on my right breast that's been getting larger and there is also some discharge from my right nipple.
I see. Is this ulcer associated with a lump in the breast?
Yes, my right breast is enlarged and feels firm.
I understand. Based on your symptoms, I would like to rule out breast cancer. Have you had any recent mammograms or biopsies?
Yes, I've had a mammogram that showed a mass and some other changes, and I also had a biopsy done recently.
I see. Based on the results of your biopsy, what was the diagnosis?
The biopsy showed that I have tumor cells invading the lymphatic vessels in the skin of my breast.

I see. Based on this information, I would diagnose you with Invasive Ductal Carcinoma with Lymphatic Involvement.

**Final Diagnosis:** Invasive Ductal Carcinoma with Lymphatic Involvement.

The biopsy showed that there are tumor cells invading the lymphatic vessels in the skin of the breast.

trial_3.summarized_mcq: The most likely diagnosis is Inflammatory breast cancer. The symptoms of a painful sore that has been present for 2 months, getting larger, and fluid coming out of the nipple, along with a family history of breast cancer, are consistent with this diagnosis. Inflammatory breast cancer is a type of breast cancer that can present with these symptoms, whereas Infiltrating lobular carcinoma and Lobular carcinoma in situ typically do not cause these symptoms and Infiltrating ductal carcinoma may present with a palpable mass but not necessarily these specific symptoms.
trial_3.summarized_frq: Infiltrative Breast Cancer (or Breast Cancer with Nipple Discharge)
